fields.description: The Mid-Atlantic ports are some of the busiest in the nation’s seaport network, which unloads $3.8 billion in goods each day.
fields.overview:
Mid-Atlantic maritime industries include shipping, transport, tourism, dredging, offshore sand mining, and some of the nation’s busiest ports at New York-New Jersey, Philadelphia, Wilmington, Baltimore, and Norfolk. These ports are crucial links in the nation’s transportation system, constitute a key element of the economy, employ many thousands of people, and have the potential to serve as environmental stewards of our region’s harbors and surrounds.

The U.S. seaport network unloads $3.8 billion in goods each day and Mid-Atlantic ports are a huge contributor, maintaining several national distinctions. The country’s top port for fruits and juices is Wilmington; the fourth busiest tanker port is Philadelphia; products that go through Baltimore’s ports reach over a third of the country within a day and anything entering the U.S. on wheels--from cars to giant tractors--alight in Baltimore, making it the nation’s top Ro-Ro (roll on-roll off) port. The world’s largest natural deep water harbor is at Hampton Roads and it stays ice-free throughout the year, making it suitable for a conglomeration of military facilities, coal piers, shipyards, and miles of waterfront property and beaches which add to the diversity and stability of our nation. The region supports important points of departure for the nation’s cruise ship industry and, in 2011, close to one million people vacationed on ocean cruises originating in New York and Baltimore.

The MARCO Ocean Data Portal contains Automatic Identification System (AIS) information from 2009, processed to focus on highly travelled shipping routes near port entrances. AIS data are collected by the U.S. Coast Guard using automated two-way radio transmissions that track real-time vessel information such as ship identity, purpose, course, and speed, primarily in coastal waters. AIS is required on all passenger vessels and vessels with gross tonnage greater than 300, so smaller vessel traffic is not represented in the database. MARCO is currently consulting with the Coast Guard and shipping industry stakeholders to evaluate how well these data indicate total ship traffic density and what additional data may be needed to fully represent shipping activity.

The viability, safety, and growth needs of the commercial shipping industry need to be addressed in regional ocean planning. Accordingly, MARCO will consult with major port and navigation stakeholders to evaluate what additional map data may be needed to inform regional ocean planning decisions and help ensure stakeholder interests are well represented.
fields.name: maritime-industries

fields.description: The Mid-Atlantic region is well known for nutrient-rich and highly productive waters. Its estuaries, salt marshes, sea grasses, barrier islands, cold water corals, and submarine canyons provide spawning, nursery, and forage habitats that support diverse resident and migratory marine life including invertebrates, seabirds, fishes, and marine mammals.
fields.overview:
The Mid-Atlantic is well known for nutrient-rich and highly productive waters. The region is a transitional area between the rocky shores of New England and the gently sloping South Atlantic, and it is influenced by two large estuaries, Chesapeake Bay and Delaware Bay. As a result, the Mid-Atlantic region is home to a wealth of complex ecosystems and its estuaries, salt marshes, sea grasses, barrier islands, cold water corals, and submarine canyons provide spawning, nursery, and forage habitats that support diverse resident and migratory marine life including invertebrates, seabirds, fishes, and marine mammals.

The topography is mostly flat, but features sandy shoals and swales, sand wedges and waves, and a broad continental shelf embedded cold water coral patch habitats and incised by submarine canyons along the shelf-slope break. These areas support biologically diverse and abundant benthic (seafloor) macrofauna, demersal fish, and foraging concentrations of sea birds, sea ducks, and bottlenose dolphins. Benthic habitats contain over 2000 species of invertebrates such as marine worms, sponges, shrimp, crab, clams, scallops, snails, sea stars, and anemones. Another invertebrate--corals--establish reefs that are known to be habitat for black seabass and tautog though research on the locations and extents of these ecologically important patchy habitats is scant.

Demersal fish (or groundfish) are characterized by their close association with the seafloor for feeding, spawning, and juvenile nursery areas. The Mid-Atlantic region is particularly productive for demersal fish with some such as summer flounder and black seabass supporting major historic and current recreational and commercial fisheries.

Diadromous fish use both freshwater and marine habitats during their life cycle and these species have great cultural and ecological significance in the Mid-Atlantic region. The diadromous fish of the region—striped bass, alewife, American eel, American Shad, Atlantic salmon, Atlantic sturgeon, Atlantic tomcod, blueback herring, hickory shad, rainbow smelt, sea-run brook trout, and shortnose sturgeon--provide an important energy link between freshwater, estuarine, and marine food webs and many of these species are found only in the Northwest Atlantic ocean.

Large pelagic fish are migratory are typically found well above the seafloor in the water column. Pelagic species play a key ecological role as predators that regulate their prey communities and structure marine food webs. Some inhabit the region only seasonally and many of the details of their life history are not known. A selection of important species includes albacore tuna, Atlantic bluefin tuna, blue marlin, swordfish, great hammerhead shark, sand tiger shark, sandbar shark. The wide ranging distribution of these species across diverse habitat types, their roles as apex predators, and their threatened population status make them ripe for inclusion in regional spatial and conservation plans.

Marine mammals are large migratory species that use this region primarily in spring and summer when food is abundant. Due to their seasonal abundance and charismatic nature, marine mammals have a long-standing, complex relationship with humans in this region. Ten species, among them bottlenose dolphin, fin whale, harbor porpoise, humpback whale, North Atlantic right whale, and sperm whale are important cultural and biodiversity icons of the region.

Sea turtles use both oceanic (inner shelf region and offshore) and terrestrial (beach) ecosystems. Their highly migratory and long life history characteristics present unique challenges to their continued protection and recovery. Sea turtles may have once comprised an important component of the region’s coastal food webs, consuming prey including fish, invertebrates, and sea grasses. Three species of sea turtle (green, leatherback and loggerhead) are present in the Mid-Atlantic.

The varied habitats and abundant resources of the Mid-Atlantic support a highly diverse group of coastal and marine birds that depend on both the oceanic and terrestrial ecosystems of the region throughout the year. Millions of birds pass through the region, which is located along the globally significant migration corridor of the Atlantic Flyway, while traveling between breeding and wintering grounds that span the entire Western Hemisphere. Species of high conservation concern, like the Red Knot and Whimbrel depend on high quality coastal habitats for critical stopover areas. Pelagic species, like the Northern Gannet and Audubon’s Shearwater, use open water habitats during both migration and wintering seasons. Shorebirds, waterbirds and waterfowl, such as the Piping Plover, American Oystercatcher, Least Terns, Black Duck and Brant breed or feed along shorelines in the region and can be heavily impacted by increasing human pressure to these coastal systems. Many of the species occurring in the Mid-Atlantic rank as species of high conservation concern.

Tidal flows, complex seasonal temperature and circulation patterns, and varied seafloor topography combine to create both persistent and shifting habitats that serve as critical resources tracked by Mid-Atlantic marine species, and give rise to upwellings that fuel plankton blooms and key forage species such as menhaden, squid and butterfish. Millions of seabirds, invertebrates, fishes, marine mammals, and large pelagic fishes such as tunas and marlins use diverse Mid-Atlantic habitat and forage resources in specific ways. Cross shelf (east-west) migrants like summer flounder and black seabass and north-south migrants like striped bass, menhaden, and large whales all traverse the region twice a year as they move from southern and near shore locations in winter to offshore or northern locations in summer.

The MARCO Ocean Data Portal has compiled habitat data, as well as known distributions and abundances of many of the key fish, mammal, bird, and reptile species found in the Mid-Atlantic region. In the future, additional data will be added to round out the collection and to allow regional planners to make management and policy decisions that are compatible with and enhance the conservation of these animals and their ecosystem.
fields.name: conservation

fields.description: The Mid-Atlantic boasts countless opportunities for entertainment and leisure activities and has flourishing travel, tourism, and outdoor recreation industries, many of which are focused on the region’s natural features.
fields.overview:
Recreation in nature is a basic human need and reflects our values--Americans love to visit, play, and exercise in parks and other public trust lands. Recreation along the coasts and in the ocean is especially valued and, for many, is essential to their well-being and quality of life. The Mid-Atlantic boasts countless opportunities for entertainment and leisure activities and has flourishing travel, tourism, and outdoor recreation industries, many of which depend on the region’s natural coastal and marine features. Visitors come from all over the country and around the world to enjoy the beaches, wetlands, and barrier islands where they surf, fish, kayak, and participate in organized or self-guided whale and bird watching tours and other pursuits. In addition to the cultural and traditional values coastal and marine ecosystems support, recreational service and supply industries are a significant driver for jobs and the region's economy. For both ethical and economic reasons, developing sound data and information on recreational uses to support forward looking regional ocean planning decisions is critical.

The Mid-Atlantic is a prime location for underwater exploration, and scuba divers can discover a unique array of plants, animals, and historical artifacts. There are countless shipwrecks in the area, for example the 'Faithful Steward'--a British ship headed for Philadelphia in 1785 which lost most of its 250 passengers and was carrying copper coins that can still be found today on Coin Beach, Delaware--and remnants of the Civil War battle between the ironclads Monitor and Merrimac off the coast of Virginia.

Visitors who prefer to stay on--and not in--the water can experience the natural beauty of the region by sailing, power boating, kayaking, or canoeing. Surfing is also a popular sport with a long history in the region. Various surfing competitions are a big draw for pros and amateurs, as are the occasions when hurricanes bring unusually high waves to Mid-Atlantic shores. And no summary of regional outdoor activities would be complete without mention of the region’s high quality, broad sandy beaches. These beaches are often the jumping off points for diverse active and leisurely pursuits and some of the most popular spots are Virginia Beach, Ocean City, Rehoboth, Cape May, and the beaches of Long Island.

Whale watching is a well-established ecotourism activity in the Mid-Atlantic. Key attractions are the humpback and right whales that migrate through the region on their long journeys north in the spring to feed in the Gulf of Maine and south to Georgia and northern Florida in the autumn to calve. Thousands of people every year take advantage of the special opportunity to make a connection with the largest animals on the planet and to do so in a non-intrusive way. During these cruises, it is also possible to spot other marine mammals such as dolphins and seals, any of three species of sea turtles including the endangered prehistoric giant that is the leatherback, and bird species that can only be seen at sea.

The region's diverse habitats--from extensive coastal marshes and beaches to submarine canyons provide home and stopover sites for hundreds of different bird species and provide plentiful opportunity to see many different nesting and migratory species throughout the year. Many locations along the region’s barrier island coastline including Cape May, Assateague and Chincoteague Islands and the lower eastern shore of Virginia are nationally and globally renowned as premier birding destinations for casual and avid birders alike.

The MARCO Ocean Data Portal team is working with partners and stakeholders to develop data and information on recreational uses and places to enhance the ability of coastal and marine planners to account for, protect and increase coastal and marine recreation opportunities in the region.
fields.name: recreation

fields.description: Numerous federal, regional, and state political and management boundaries of the Mid-Atlantic are compiled here to provide a regulatory context to help facilitate well-informed ocean planning decisions.
fields.overview:
Numerous management boundaries in the Mid-Atlantic are compiled here to provide administrative and regulatory contexts to help facilitate well-informed ocean planning decisions.

Key boundaries include:

  • Submerged Lands Act Boundary – Also known as the state seaward boundary, this line serves to distinguish state and federal jurisdictions (3 nautical miles seaward from mean low low water [MLLW]).
  • 8g Revenue Sharing Line – area where revenues from energy resources are shared by federal and coastal state governments (extends seaward 3 nautical miles from Submerged Lands Act Boundary).
  • Territorial Sea Boundary – region of U.S. sovereignty (extends from MLLW to 12 nautical miles from shore).
  • Contiguous Zone - Each coastal state may claim a contiguous zone adjacent to and beyond its territorial sea that extends seaward up to 24 nautical miles from its baselines.
  • Exclusive Economic Zone – area of sole rights for resource use, research, and protection (extends from Territorial Sea Boundary to 200 nautical miles from shore)

Important administrative areas include:

  • OCS lease blocks – administrative boundaries generated to define small geographic areas that identify federal land ownership and support energy permitting and leasing processes by the Bureau of Ocean Energy Management.
  • OCS boundaries – unofficial approximation of boundaries between states seaward of the Submerged Lands Act Boundary.
  • Regional Ocean Partnerships – unofficial boundaries of Atlantic coast Regional Ocean Partnerships.

Note: Boundaries are provided courtesy of the responsible agencies and these parties should be consulted to ensure that map layers represented here are current and correctly interpreted. The boundaries presented here should not be considered to be legally binding.
fields.name: administrative

fields.description: The Portal will be collecting and integrating data on the productive habitats and rich species diversity that are essential for maintaining healthy fishing areas.
fields.overview:
The Mid-Atlantic’s highly productive estuaries and diverse coastal and ocean habitats support substantial commercial and recreational fisheries that provide income, food, and enjoyment for millions of people. Fishing is an essential component of the region’s rich cultural heritage and directly connects coastal community residents and tourists to the ocean, whether through fresh seafood or the thrill of a day spent fishing on the ocean.

In 2010, the Mid-Atlantic’s commercial harvest was more than 800 million pounds, with Atlantic menhaden making up over 60% of the catch. Other key commercial species include sea scallop, surf clam, ocean quahog clam, summer flounder, lobster, squid, and striped bass. The total 2010 ex-vessel value (initial price paid to fishermen) was well over $500 million and sea scallops were the most valuable of the species. But the value of commercial fisheries extends beyond ex-vessel price. In 2009, the region’s fisheries supported an estimated 116,000 jobs in industries ranging from equipment supply to seafood processing and retail. Roughly 2.6 million recreational anglers participated in 17 million saltwater fishing trips in 2009, mainly targeting striped bass, summer flounder, black seabass, tautog, scup, bluefish, drum, weakfish, spot, and croaker. They spent an estimated $3.5 billion on the fishing-related vehicles, tackle, boats, equipment, and second homes. That same year, the recreational fishing industry in the Mid-Atlantic supported approximately 25,000 jobs.

The MARCO Ocean Data Portal includes commercial fishing effort for mobile bottom-contacting gear (e.g., trawls and dredges), pelagic gear (e.g., mid-water trawls, gill nets, and hook and line), and all gear combined. The map layers were created using Fishing Vessel Trip Report data provided by the National Marine Fisheries Service. These data are presented at a coarse spatial scale (i.e., 70-100 square nautical miles) and illustrate the regional importance of commercial fishing areas, but are less than ideal for coastal and marine planning. Further, MARCO does not include specific recreational fishing information, although for-hire sector fishing effort is included in the commercial pelagic gear map layer.

MARCO is working to improve the commercial fishing data represented here and to add recreational fishing information. Planned improvements include creation of higher resolution commercial fishing activity maps and development of products--in conjunction with stakeholders--that best represent commercial fishing interests and values, while protecting confidential information. Efforts to create maps of recreational use areas are being developed with assistance from anglers in all Mid-Atlantic states, and a new online recreational boater survey to enhance these efforts is being designed for implementation in late 2012.

The Mid-Atlantic Fisheries Management Council and the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission have management authority for most recreational and commercial ocean fisheries. Some migratory species (e.g., sharks and tunas), are managed separately by the National Marine Fisheries Service. MARCO will coordinate and consult with all of these institutions as appropriate to acquire and develop fishing data suitable for public display.
fields.name: fishing

fields.description: Offshore wind in the Mid-Atlantic holds more than 60,000 Megawatts of potential energy — that’s 10% of total U.S. offshore potential. This huge resource could help meet the growing electricity demand in the region, while reducing carbon emissions.
fields.overview:
Offshore wind has the potential to be a key domestic renewable energy source, especially for the major cities and large population centers along the East coast of the U.S. The Mid-Atlantic’s offshore wind resources have the potential to produce close to 200 gigawatts of energy every year, enough to power 40 million U.S. homes. Someday, the region’s ocean wave energy could generate an additional 50,000 gigawatts of power and contribute even more significantly to the U.S. energy supply. These renewable energy sources could help meet growing electricity demands in the region and help to reduce carbon emissions.

Production of electricity from renewable sources, such as wind and ocean waves, may be less damaging to the environment than production through burning of fossil fuels, like oil, natural gas, and coal because renewable energy facilities produce much lower emissions of greenhouse gasses and other harmful pollutants such as arsenic, lead and mercury. Additionally, renewable energy production may be more cost effective and efficient than traditional methods because once infrastructure is built, the amount of energy produced is quite stable for the remainder of that system’s lifespan. While the inputs (wind and waves) may fluctuate daily or seasonally they should remain consistent over longer time scales, allowing producers and consumers to rely on steady energy levels.

The Department of the Interior has identified Wind Planning Areas (WPA)--locations that may be suitable for wind development--along the Atlantic Ocean’s outer shelf. Data are being collected inside and outside these high priority areas so regulators and stakeholders can make informed and responsible judgments when issuing permits and making siting and investment decisions. Annual average wind speeds are an indication of the potential available energy at a location. Here, wind speeds modeled from limited observations by the National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) and AWS Truepower are expressed at a height of 90 meters above the ocean surface where wind turbine hubs are likely to be located.

Not all the wind and waves that exist offshore are available for harvest however, and all potential energy estimates should be constrained to account for various environmental and socioeconomic factors that may exist in an area. Some of these constraints include potential overlapping use conflicts with shipping lanes, marine mammal, bird, and bat migration pathways, and traditional areas for fishing and recreational use. Infrastructure may need to be built far enough from shore to address concerns over impacts to scenic views, but close enough that the cost of bringing the electricity to shore is not prohibitive. All of these issues should be accounted for in regional ocean planning and the MARCO Ocean Data Portal provides key information that will help to raise awareness of the potential for renewable energy and support decision maker’s efforts to manage resources effectively and minimize conflicts.
fields.name: energy

fields.description: The Mid-Atlantic is home to important naval installations and training areas, and it’s a busy corridor for commercial shipping and naval and other defense and security operations.
fields.overview:
The Mid-Atlantic region is a busy corridor for commercial and recreational ship traffic and is home to the world’s largest naval base, as well as many other military installations and training grounds. The U.S. Coast Guard works with other agencies to ensure that navigation routes for both commercial and defense vessels are accessible and safe. Their security focus is on the safety of ports, vessels, and facilities, both on and away from shore and their presence is notable throughout the region, with bases in Norfolk, Baltimore, Cape May, and Staten Island.

The Naval Station at Norfolk, Virginia supports 75 large ships and 130 aircraft on seven miles of piers and wharfs, and it houses the largest concentration of Navy personnel in the country. Every year, its Port Services branch oversees more than 3,000 maneuvers as ships arrive and depart their berths. Spatial planners and resource managers must account for this intensive activity and work with military leaders to ensure their missions are not compromised as planning decisions are made.

The legal framework supporting maritime security in the U.S. is based on five principal laws:

  • Espionage Act (1917) – enabled the Coast Guard to make regulations to prevent losses to harbors and vessels during national emergencies.
  • Magnusson Act (1950) – provided permanent port security regulations and allowance to control movement of foreign vessels in U.S. ports.
  • Ports and Waterways Safety Act (1972) – allowed additional protection for port facilities and improved efforts to avoid degrading the marine environment.
  • Maritime Transportation Security Act (2002) – provided broad authority to prevent acts of terrorism within U.S. waters.
  • International Ship and Port Facility Security Code (2002) – amendments to International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea to enhance maritime security.

Data under development for the Security theme will include areas with potential hazards or public use restrictions and other information deemed to be critical for spatial planning. To ensure that security interests are fully considered, regional ocean planning leads will include defense representatives and officials responsible for maintaining the security of our vessels, ports and Nation.
fields.name: security

fields.description: We are currently developing data related to Recreational Boating Activities as well as Areas for Non-Fishing, Non-Boating Recreational Use.
fields.name: Recreation Data Layers

fields.description: Outer Continental Shelf lease blocks.
fields.data_overview: Outer Continental Shelf (OCS) lease blocks and administrative boundaries are generated to define small geographic areas that identify federal land ownership and support offshore resource management.
fields.data_source: Bureau of Ocean Energy Management via Multipurpose Marine Cadastre
fields.data_notes: Outer Continental Shelf Lease Blocks are used to assist in leasing on the Outer Continental Shelf. Blocks are numbered areas depicted on the Official Protraction Diagrams or Leasing Maps. Most are of a uniform size according to the projection and type of map on which they are depicted, but many are of non-uniform size and shape due to their proximity to an adjacent map, projection zone, or boundary. Blocks should always be referred to with their parent protraction name or number since block numbers repeat from one protraction to the next.
fields.name: OCS Lease Blocks

fields.description: Administrative boundaries extending from the Submerged Lands Act boundary seaward to the US Outer Continental Shelf.
fields.data_overview: Administrative Boundaries extending from the Submerged Lands Act Boundary seaward to the limit of the United States Outer Continental Shelf (The U.S. 200 nautical mile limit, or other marine boundary).
fields.data_source: Bureau of Ocean Energy Management via Multipurpose Marine Cadastre
fields.data_notes: These boundaries were created for BOEM administrative purposes only, such as delineating BOEM planning areas or determining shared state revenue sharing within the 3 nautical mile zone seaward of the SLA boundary known as the Revenue Sharing Boundary. They were created using the equidistant principle used to divide offshore areas between countries as defined within the UNCLOS.  They are not meant to depict areas offshore as pertaining to or controlled by any particular state.
fields.name: OCS Boundaries

fields.description: This dataset shows general polygon locations of Mid-Atlantic artificial reefs.
fields.data_overview: These are polygon locations of Mid-Atlantic artificial reefs. These data usually represent general polygons within which artificial reef material has been deposited--the entirety of each polygon is not necessarily all artificial reef.
fields.data_notes: These data were compiled from various state sources. In Delaware, Digital data were received directly from a state agency. The Nature Conservancy compiled reef data from numerous sources in Maryland, including state agencies. For the remaining states, GIS data was created from lat/long coordinates of reef corners found on public web sites (i.e., New York DEC, New Jersey DEP, Virginia MRC).
fields.name: Artificial Reefs

fields.description: This data layer shows both the coastal vulnerability index (CVI) and the data from which the CVI is calculated (tides, wave height, relative sea-level rise, coastal slope, geomorphology, and shoreline erosion and accretion rate) for the U.S. Atlantic Coast.
fields.data_overview:
The goal of this project is to provide a preliminary overview of the relative susceptibility of the Nation's coast to sea-level rise through the use of a coastal vulnerability index (CVI). This initial classification is based upon the variables geomorphology, regional coastal slope, tide range, wave height, relative sea-level rise and shoreline erosion and accretion rates. The combination of these variables and their association to each other furnish a broad overview of regions where physical changes are likely to occur due to sea-level rise.

The purpose of this data layer is to allow the user to view both the coastal vulnerability index (CVI) and the data from which the CVI is calculated (tides, wave height, relative sea-level rise, coastal slope, geomorphology, and shoreline erosion and accretion rate) for the U.S. Atlantic Coast. The CVI provides insight into the relative potential for coastal change due to future sea-level rise.
fields.data_notes: These data were created to be used for planning purposes only. They are designed to give a broad overview of vulnerability to sea level rise at a National scale.
fields.name: Sea Level Rise Vulnerability

fields.description: This data layer represents major canyons of the Mid-Atlantic Coast, and the approximate boundaries were digitized on-screen over a raster bathymetry layer.
fields.data_overview: This data layer represents major canyons of the Mid-Atlantic Coast. Approximate boundaries were digitized on-screen over a raster bathymetry layer. Canyon names come from NOAA charts and other various sources. These boundaries were created primarily for cartographic purposes and do not represent ecological boundaries.
fields.data_notes: These data were primarily created to be used for cartographic purposes. There are many submarine canyons in addition to those included here – this layer was created in an attempt to show the “major” canyons on maps.
fields.name: Submarine Canyons

fields.description: These data represent cables that have been laid underwater or buried beneath the seabed. This layer was created to allow for visualization, querying and downloading of NOAA’s Electronic Navigational Charts.
fields.data_overview: These data represent cables that have been laid underwater or buried beneath the seabed. This layer was created to allow for visualization, querying and downloading of NOAA’s Electronic Navigational Charts.
fields.data_notes: NOAA ENC Direct to GIS data is not intended for navigational purposes. This data is provided for use in GIS software packages for coastal planning and research.
fields.name: Submarine Cables

fields.description: Areas necessary for spawning, breeding, feeding, or growth to maturity of key fish species, including: American Plaice, Atlantic Halibut, Atlantic Herring, Haddock, Monkfish, Ocean Pout, Offshore Hake, Pollock, Redfish, Red Hake, Sea Scallop, Silver Hake, Tilefish, White Hake, Windowpane Flounder, Winter Flounder, Witch Flounder, and Yellowtail Flounder.
fields.data_overview:
Essential Fish Habitat (EFH) is defined as those waters and substrate necessary to fish for spawning, breeding, feeding, or growth to maturity (16 U.S.C. 1802(10)). Waters include aquatic areas and their associated physical, chemical, and biological properties that are used by fish and may include aquatic areas historically used by fish where appropriate; substrate includes sediment, hard bottom, structures underlying the waters, and associated biological communities; necessary means the habitat required to support a sustainable fishery and the managed species' contribution to a healthy ecosystem; and spawning, breeding, feeding, or growth to maturity covers a species' full life cycle.

This particular layer represents an overlay of EFH polygons for numerous species. The Nature Conservancy obtained individual EFH layers from NOAA. The data presented here do not represent EFH for individual species but rather the number of overlapping EFH in any given location. 

The following species are included in the overlay: American Plaice, Atlantic Halibut, Atlantic Herring, Haddock, Monkfish, Ocean Pout, Offshore Hake, Pollock, Redfish, Red Hake, Sea Scallop, Silver Hake, Tilefish, White Hake, Windowpane Flounder, Winter Flounder, Witch Flounder, and Yellowtail Flounder.
fields.data_notes: This layer was developed for general visualization and informational purposes only and does not necessarily represent the most important habitats. Additionally, only certain species were included in this analysis; included species are those under Federal management for which spatial data exists. There are numerous managed species for which spatial data does not yet exist. See below for a list of the species considered.
fields.name: Essential Fish Habitat

fields.description: Depth contours at 20, 50, and 100 fathoms.
fields.data_notes: These are lines of varying depths provided primarily for general reference. The depths selected are those that may be familiar to fisherman and others who navigate offshore waters.
fields.name: Fathom Lines

fields.description: This data set shows benthic habitats based on Ecological Marine Units (EMUs), which represent the three-way combination of depth, sediment grain size and seabed forms based on the ecological thresholds revealed by the organism relationships.
fields.data_overview: Benthic habitats are based on Ecological Marine Units (EMUs), which represent the three-way combination of depth, sediment grain size and seabed forms based on the ecological thresholds revealed by the organism relationships. Benthic habitats are combinations of EMUs considered with their species assemblages. Thresholds were created by classifying grab samples into organism groups based on similarities in the composition and abundance of the benthic species using hierarchical cluster analysis. To perform this analysis, each grab sample was classified to an organism group, then overlaid on standardized base maps of depth, sediment grain size and seabed forms, and attributed with the information taken from the classified data. Regression trees were built individually for each physical variable to identify critical thresholds that separated sets of organism groups from each other. Regression trees were also built using all variables collectively to identify which variables were driving the organism differences. Each analysis was performed separately by ecological subregion after data exploration revealed that the relationships between genera and physical factors differed markedly among subregions.
fields.data_notes: This data product was created as part of the Northwest Atlantic Marine Ecoregional Assessment. The Nature Conservancy developed this science-based ecoregional assessment for the Northwest Atlantic Marine region (Bay of Fundy to Cape Hatteras, North Carolina). This assessment synthesizes information on oceanography, chemistry, geology, biology, and social science to inform decisions about coastal and marine ecosystems. The ten categories of targets identified as the primary structure for the marine ecoregional assessment are: coastal and estuarine habitats, benthic habitats, diadromous fish, demersal fish, pelagic fish, forage fish, nearshore shellfish, shorebirds and seabirds, marine mammals, and sea turtles. For more information and a detailed report, please visit http://nature.org/namera/.
fields.name: Benthic Habitats (South)

fields.description: This data layer was created from interpolation of usSEABED point data and analyzes the averaged grain-size for each sample to produce a robust interpretation of sediment texture, showing local variation as well as large-scale patterns.
fields.data_overview: This layer was created from interpolation of usSEABED point data. usSEABED's averaged grain-size for each sample produced a robust interpretation of sediment texture, showing local variation as well as large-scale patterns. The point samples were interpolated using the Kriging interpolation method in ArcGIS to create surfaces representing the area between sample points at a cell size of 500 meters. These data were created to be used for planning purposes only at an ecoregional scale. The source sediment data were point data that in some cases is very widely spaced. We classified grain-size according to organisms' preferences, and assigned names to these classes based on the Wentworth (1922) scheme.
fields.data_notes: This data product was created as part of the Northwest Atlantic Marine Ecoregional Assessment. The Nature Conservancy developed this science-based ecoregional assessment for the Northwest Atlantic Marine region (Bay of Fundy to Cape Hatteras, North Carolina). This assessment synthesizes information on oceanography, chemistry, geology, biology, and social science to inform decisions about coastal and marine ecosystems. The ten categories of targets identified as the primary structure for the marine ecoregional assessment are: coastal and estuarine habitats, benthic habitats, diadromous fish, demersal fish, pelagic fish, forage fish, nearshore shellfish, shorebirds and seabirds, marine mammals, and sea turtles. For more information and a detailed report, please visit http://nature.org/namera/.
fields.name: Sediment Grain Size

fields.data_notes: The Atlantic Wind Connection (AWC) is a proposed undersea transmission cable system that would bring power generated by Mid-Atlantic offshore wind turbines to shore. The private-sector project would span approximately 350 miles from northern New Jersey to southern Virginia and would be built in phases over a 10-year period.
fields.name: AWC Routes & Hubs

fields.description: This geospatial data set, obtained from the United States Navy, includes point shapefiles of valid sightings for numerous marine mammal and turtle species, and pre-calculated effort grids for each season.
fields.name: Sperm Whales (Summer)

fields.description: This data set shows benthic habitats based on Ecological Marine Units (EMUs), which represent the three-way combination of depth, sediment grain size and seabed forms based on the ecological thresholds revealed by the organism relationships.
fields.data_overview: Benthic habitats are based on Ecological Marine Units (EMUs), which represent the three-way combination of depth, sediment grain size and seabed forms based on the ecological thresholds revealed by the organism relationships. Benthic habitats are combinations of EMUs considered with their species assemblages. Thresholds were created by classifying grab samples into organism groups based on similarities in the composition and abundance of the benthic species using hierarchical cluster analysis. To perform this analysis, each grab sample was classified to an organism group, then overlaid on standardized base maps of depth, sediment grain size and seabed forms, and attributed with the information taken from the classified data. Regression trees were built individually for each physical variable to identify critical thresholds that separated sets of organism groups from each other. Regression trees were also built using all variables collectively to identify which variables were driving the organism differences. Each analysis was performed separately by ecological subregion after data exploration revealed that the relationships between genera and physical factors differed markedly among subregions.
fields.data_notes: This data product was created as part of the Northwest Atlantic Marine Ecoregional Assessment. The Nature Conservancy developed this science-based ecoregional assessment for the Northwest Atlantic Marine region (Bay of Fundy to Cape Hatteras, North Carolina). This assessment synthesizes information on oceanography, chemistry, geology, biology, and social science to inform decisions about coastal and marine ecosystems. The ten categories of targets identified as the primary structure for the marine ecoregional assessment are: coastal and estuarine habitats, benthic habitats, diadromous fish, demersal fish, pelagic fish, forage fish, nearshore shellfish, shorebirds and seabirds, marine mammals, and sea turtles. For more information and a detailed report, please visit http://nature.org/namera/.
fields.name: Benthic Habitats (North)

fields.description: This data layer contains waterbird density blocks extracted from the Minerals Management Service's Mid-Atlantic Waterbird Data Beta Version 1.0. The spatial extent of the database (and thus of this data set) is from the Virginia/North Carolina border to the Hudson Canyon (including Delaware Bay and the lowest part of Chesapeake Bay).
fields.data_overview:
This data layer contains waterbird density blocks extracted from the Minerals Management Service's Mid-Atlantic Waterbird Data Beta Version 1.0. This application is based on their Marine Mammal and Seabird Computer Database Analysis System (MMS-CDAS). The origin of the underlying data is a U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service aerial survey conducted between December 2001 and March 2003.

All waterbird species in the USFWS database from winter surveys only were exported to density blocks. Information in the MMS application suggests the winter surveys only are valid for calculating densities because they were flown on specific transects. The spatial extent of the database (and thus of this data set) is from the Virginia/North Carolina border to the Hudson Canyon (including Delaware Bay and the lowest part of Chesapeake Bay).
fields.data_notes: These data were created from only one study and only represent where birds were observed during that time period. In addition, this layer currently only shows data for all species grouped together. There may be cases where it would be better to consider individual species or smaller groupings of similar species.
fields.name: Waterbird Survey
fields.legend_title:
Waterbird Survey

(# birds per sq km)

fields.description: Areas necessary for spawning, breeding, feeding, or growth to maturity of key fish species, including: American Plaice, Atlantic Halibut, Atlantic Herring, Haddock, Monkfish, Ocean Pout, Offshore Hake, Pollock, Redfish, Red Hake, Sea Scallop, Silver Hake, Tilefish, White Hake, Windowpane Flounder, Winter Flounder, Witch Flounder, and Yellowtail Flounder.
fields.data_overview:
Essential Fish Habitat (EFH) is defined as those waters and substrate necessary to fish for spawning, breeding, feeding, or growth to maturity (16 U.S.C. 1802(10)). Waters include aquatic areas and their associated physical, chemical, and biological properties that are used by fish and may include aquatic areas historically used by fish where appropriate; substrate includes sediment, hard bottom, structures underlying the waters, and associated biological communities; necessary means the habitat required to support a sustainable fishery and the managed species' contribution to a healthy ecosystem; and spawning, breeding, feeding, or growth to maturity covers a species' full life cycle.

This particular layer represents an overlay of EFH polygons for numerous species. The Nature Conservancy obtained individual EFH layers from NOAA. The data presented here do not represent EFH for individual species but rather the number of overlapping EFH in any given location. 

The following species are included in the overlay: American Plaice, Atlantic Halibut, Atlantic Herring, Haddock, Monkfish, Ocean Pout, Offshore Hake, Pollock, Redfish, Red Hake, Sea Scallop, Silver Hake, Tilefish, White Hake, Windowpane Flounder, Winter Flounder, Witch Flounder, and Yellowtail Flounder.
fields.data_notes: This layer was developed for general visualization and informational purposes only and does not necessarily represent the most important habitats. Additionally, only certain species were included in this analysis; included species are those under Federal management for which spatial data exists. There are numerous managed species for which spatial data does not yet exist. See below for a list of the species considered.
fields.name: EFH Overlays

fields.description: Annual average wind speeds are closely related to the available energy at a particular location. In these data, wind speeds are categorized by their value at a height of 90 meters above the surface. The data were created by the National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) and AWS Truepower.
fields.data_overview: Annual average wind speeds are closely related to the available energy at a particular location. In these data, wind speeds are categorized by their value at a height of 90 meters above the surface. The data were created by the National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) and AWS Truepower. Wind speed data for all of the MARCO states was created as part of onshore wind mapping projects. Speed data was extrapolated to 50 nautical miles offshore by NREL. The 90 m wind speed was calculated by a linear interpolation between 70 m and 100 m wind speeds. A horizontal discontinuity (seam) in the wind resource is present at the border of New York and New Jersey. Discontinuities in the data result from offshore data that is based on different versions of the numerical model used for the different onshore mapping projects and the way the extrapolation software interprets the data on either side of the seam.
fields.data_notes: This layer represents an estimate of offshore annual average wind speeds and is based primarily on data extrapolated from onshore wind data, which is a source of uncertainty in the dataset. For more information visit nrel.gov and search for Technical Report TP-500-45889.
fields.name: Wind Speed

fields.description: This data set, obtained from the United States Navy, include point shapefiles of valid sightings for numerous marine mammal and turtle species, and pre-calculated effort grids for each season.
fields.data_overview: Sightings per unit effort aggregated to ten minute squares.
fields.data_source: The Nature Conservancy and U.S. Navy
fields.data_notes: Sightings data obtained from the U.S. Navy were taken from NMFS-NEFSC Aerial Surveys, NMFS-NEFSC Shipboard Surveys, and the North Atlantic Right Whale Consortium database. The validity of sightings was carefully screened and verified by United States Navy contractors before inclusion in the model. Invalid records were not included in the analysis. Sightings for each ten minute square were divided by the effort for each ten minute square to calculate Sightings Per Unit Effort (SPUE).  SPUE was calculated for each species, for each season, and for each ten minute square.
fields.name: Marine Mammals

fields.description: Standardized compilation of published marine boundaries.
fields.data_overview: The Marine Jurisdiction data set is a standardized compilation of published marine boundaries from the NOAA Office of Coast Survey and the Bureau of Ocean Energy Management.
fields.data_source: Bureau of Ocean Energy Management and NOAA Office of Coast Survey via Multipurpose Marine Cadastre
fields.data_notes: This is a composite dataset that includes the state seaward boundary, revenue sharing boundary, territorial sea, contiguous zone and exclusive economic zone. The boundaries shown here should not be construed as legally binding.
fields.name: Marine Jurisdictions

fields.description: This layer represents areas of high avian density that were identified based on a ranking procedure, in which the individual grid boxes with non-zero densities were ranked in the order of highest to lowest total density, and those grid boxes that rank in the top 20 percent of all non-zero-density grid boxes were designated as high-density grid boxes.
fields.data_overview: This layer represents areas of high avian density that were identified based on a ranking procedure, in which the individual grid boxes with non-zero densities (i.e., those grid boxes with at least one bird sighting) were ranked in the order of highest to lowest total density, and those grid boxes that rank in the top 20 percent of all non-zero-density grid boxes were designated as high-density grid boxes (i.e., regions of high avian density). This is based on observations recorded from offshore ship surveys conducted between January 2008 and December 2009.
fields.data_source: New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection
fields.data_notes: This data layer was created for use in the New Jersey Ocean/Wind Power Ecological Baseline Study. The overall goal of the study is to provide spatial and temporal data on species utilizing New Jersey offshore waters to assist in determining potential areas for wind power development. This layer represents a summary of all birds and all behaviors over the entire 2 year study. Data aggregated by month, season and species are also available. Additional modeling of avian densities was also done and is included in the overall environmental sensitivity index.
fields.name: Important Bird Habitats

fields.description: This data set is derived from archived 2009 Automatic Identification System (AIS) data, and the Density grid depicts the concentration of a majority of commercial shipping traffic within U.S. coastal and offshore waters. The data set is intended to be used by the ocean planning community to better understand vessel traffic patterns.
fields.data_overview:
Automatic Identification System (AIS) data are collected by the U.S. Coast Guard using automated two-way radio transmissions to track real-time vessel information such as ship identity, purpose, course, and speed, primarily in coastal U.S. waters.  This data set is derived from archived 2009 AIS data and is intended to be used by the ocean planning community to better understand vessel traffic patterns.

The AIS Vessel Trackline Density grid depicts the concentration of a majority of commercial shipping traffic within U.S. coastal and offshore waters. The density grid was created using tracklines that were generated from a 2009 AIS Database using a custom built trackline tool. Vessel tracklines were created separately for each month using the file geodatabases for UTM zones 18 and 19. A unique density grid was created for each combination of month and UTM zone. These grids were then summed together and clipped to the Mid-Atlantic region. To simplify display in on-line data viewers, the summed floating point grid was reclassified into 7 discrete classes using increments of 1/2 standard deviations from the mean density value from 1/2 to 3 standard deviations.
fields.data_notes: This is a simplified view of a very complex and detailed data set. Hundreds of millions of individual points were processed and condensed into a generalized density raster. This raster shows a good overview of the density of most commercial shipping traffic but does not necessarily represent all shipping traffic at a fine level of detail.
fields.name: AIS Shipping Data

fields.description: This data set represents ship traffic separation zones, which separate the lanes in which ships proceed in opposite or nearly opposite directions or separate traffic lanes designated for particular classes of ships proceeding in the same direction.
fields.data_overview: This represents ship traffic separation zones, which separate the lanes in which ships proceed in opposite or nearly opposite directions or separate traffic lanes designated for particular classes of ships proceeding in the same direction.
fields.data_notes: NOAA ENC Direct to GIS data is not intended for navigational purposes. This data is provided for use in GIS software packages for coastal planning and research.
fields.name: Ship Traffic Separation Zones

fields.description: This data product represents fishing effort (average number of trips) by federally permitted commercial fishing vessels from 2000 to 2009 for all gear types.
fields.data_overview: This is an extract of Fishing Vessel Trip Report (FVTR) data that The Nature Conservancy compiled from raw data received from the National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS).
fields.data_notes: This is an extract of Fishing Vessel Trip Report (FVTR) data that The Nature Conservancy compiled from raw data received from the National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS). The owner/operator of a vessel issued a federal fishery permit with FVTR requirements is required to submit FVTRs for each trip taken. The National Marine Fisheries Service requires this information for the conservation and management of marine fishery resources in accordance with the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act. The data reported are used to develop, implement, and monitor fishery management strategies and for a variety of other uses. These data are sufficient for general planning purposes but errors in reporting or in transferring the paper reports to a digital format are not uncommon.
fields.name: All Gear Types

fields.description: This data set identfies Wind Planning Areas (WPA) on the Outer Continental Shelf (OCS) off the Atlantic coast. WPAs are offshore locations that appear most suitable for wind energy development. Data has been and will continue to be collected for these high priority areas to inform government and industry assessments and planning, allowing a more efficient process for permitting and siting responsible development.
fields.data_overview: The Department of the Interior's "Smart from the Start" initiative calls for the identification of Wind Planning Areas (WPA) on the Outer Continental Shelf (OCS) off the Atlantic coast. WPAs are offshore locations that appear most suitable for wind energy development. Data has been and will continue to be collected for these high priority areas to inform government and industry assessments and planning, allowing a more efficient process for permitting and siting responsible development. Requests for Interest (RFIs) and Calls for Information have been or will be issued for these new WEAs to support lease sale environmental assessments.
fields.data_notes: The data was developed within the U.S. Government; no proprietary rights may be attached to them nor may they be sold to the U.S. Government as part of any procurement of ADP products or services.
fields.name: Wind Planning Areas

fields.description: This data set is comprised of seabed position calculations that describe the topography of the area surrounding a particular cell on the seafloor. The calculations based on Fels and Zobel's (1995) method, which evaluates the elevation differences between the model cell and the surrounding cells within a specified distance.
fields.data_overview: Seabed forms classify seafloor topography into discrete units. Derived from The Nature Conservancy's digital bathymetry, seabed forms can be described by a combination of just two variables: seabed position and slope. Seabed position (also referred to as topographic position or slope position) describes the topography of the area surrounding a particular cell. We based our seabed position calculations on Fels and Zobel's (1995) method, which evaluates the elevation differences between the model cell and the surrounding cells within a specified distance.
fields.data_notes: This data product was created as part of the Northwest Atlantic Marine Ecoregional Assessment. The Nature Conservancy developed this science-based ecoregional assessment for the Northwest Atlantic Marine region (Bay of Fundy to Cape Hatteras, North Carolina). This assessment synthesizes information on oceanography, chemistry, geology, biology, and social science to inform decisions about coastal and marine ecosystems. The ten categories of targets identified as the primary structure for the marine ecoregional assessment are: coastal and estuarine habitats, benthic habitats, diadromous fish, demersal fish, pelagic fish, forage fish, nearshore shellfish, shorebirds and seabirds, marine mammals, and sea turtles. For more information and a detailed report, please visit http://nature.org/namera/.
fields.name: Seabed Forms

fields.description: This data set represents fishing effort (days fished) and landings for one species (summer flounder) compiled by ten-minute square (areas that are 10 minutes of longitude by 10 minutes of latitude) for a 10-year period (2000-2009).
fields.data_overview: This data set represents fishing effort (days fished) and landings for one species (summer flounder) compiled by ten-minute square (areas that are 10 minutes of longitude by 10 minutes of latitude) for a 10-year period (2000-2009). The fishing effort data are broken down by various gear types. In the MARCO portal the data are displayed for a sum of all gear types, for a sum of all bottom contacting mobile gear (mostly dredges and bottom trawls) and for a sum of pelagic gear types.

fields.notes: Data has been transferred from NMFS and will need to be processed to provide maximum utility in consideration of confidentiality requirements.
fields.description: VMS are required for many commercial fisheries to monitor the position, time at a position, course and speed of fishing vessels.

fields.status: No efforts currently underway to obtain and compile data
fields.name: Important coastal bird habitat
fields.notes: Need to leverage existing data and efforts; additional data needs to be collected.
fields.description: Point and polygon data on coastal bird use of coastal and marine habitats for nesting, breeding, wintering and stopover.

fields.status: Efforts underway to incorporate authorized data into Portal
fields.name: Turtles-Sightings per Unit Effort (SPUE)
fields.expected_date: As soon as vetted by Portal Data Review Team
fields.notes: Need to add summary SPUE grid for all three species assessed (green, leatherback and Atlantic loggerhead turtles) across seasons.
fields.source: TNC NAM ERA compiled data;  source of data U.S. Navy Marine Resource Assessment (MRA) for the Northeast and Virginia Capes
fields.description: Important areas for sea turtles were determined from point sightings data. Data were assessed, combined and converted from seasonal species sightings into ten minute squares and effort-corrected.  The resulting sightings per unit effort (SPUE) grids were used to identify important areas within the region for each species.

fields.name: Automatic Identification System (AIS) shipping data
fields.description: AIS is an automated tracking system used on ships and by Vessel Traffic Services for identifying and locating vessels by electronically exchanging data with other nearby ships and VTS stations. AIS provides information such as unique identification, position, course, and speed.

fields.name: Cultural use areas
fields.notes: Development and use of these data based on outcome of discussions between Tribal leaders and state and federal agency representatives.
fields.description: Areas significant to Tribal Nations and other cultures.

fields.status: Efforts underway to incorporate authorized data into Portal
fields.name: Large Pelagic Species (sharks, tuna, marlin)-Species Richness, Persistence and EFH
fields.expected_date: As soon as vetted by Portal Data Review Team
fields.notes: 14 species represented include: Albacore Tuna, Bigeye Thresher, Blue Marlin, Bluefin Tuna, Dusky shark, Great Hammerhead, Porbeagle, Sandbar shark, Sand Tiger, Shortfin Mako, Swordfish, Thresher, White Marlin, Scalloped Hammerhead
fields.source: TNC NAM ERA compiled; source data from NMFS- SEFSC and NMFS-NEFSC; EFH from NMFS and HMS FMP
fields.description: Target species richness refers to the total number of target species by age class observed within a TMS summed and mapped based on all available data (1965-2004).  Persistence refers to the sum of the number of decades that a given target species was present (1-4) for combined juvenile and adult observations.  Habitat refers to the number of target species whose EFH overlapped each TMS determined and summarized by total target species and by age class.

fields.name: Recreational boating activity
fields.notes: Initial data is being collected via participatory GIS workshops with recreational stakeholders, summer 2012 and will continue through the fall and winter; these efforts will be supplemented by other surveys planned for 2013.
fields.source: Recreational boaters via MARCO stakeholder engagement efforts
fields.description: Areas where recreational boating (regattas, pleasure, cruises, water skiing, etc.) occurs.

fields.status: Efforts underway to develop and incorporate authorized data into Portal
fields.name: Military, hazard and restricted areas
fields.source: USCG & DOD including ACOE, Navy, etc.
fields.description: Information pertaining to uses of the marine environment by the Department of Defense for training, classified or restricted areas, with unexploded ordinances, etc.

fields.name: Marine mammal migration paths
fields.notes: Multiple data collection efforts ongoing currently, including AMAPPS (funded by BOEM), BRI study (funded by DOE), and VA Aquarium study (funded by VACZM).
fields.source: DOE grant to BRI. VA CZM Section 309 grant to VA Aquarium, others to be determined.
fields.description: Critical seasonal migratory pathways for large whales (toothed and baleen), dolphins and porpoises.

fields.name: Commercial fishing activity
fields.notes: These data will supplement or replace the relatively coarse scale VTR data currently displayed. Data will be processed in consultation with commercial fishery stakeholders to maximize its value for planning while maintaining appropriate confidentiality. Additional finer scale VTR derived data products will not be displayed without prior stakeholder review and approval by NMFS authorities.
fields.source: Commercial fishers via MARCO stakeholder engagement efforts
fields.description: Spatial data interpreted and created using National Marine Fisheries Service Fishing Vessel Trip Report (VTR) databases summarized and mapped in consultation with commercial fishing stakeholders to illustrate the distribution, timing, and intensity of commercial fishing activity, with attributes for gear type and harvest species. Additional attributes collected through stakeholder engagement may include information about the specific socio-economic and cultural values of fishing locations to communities.

fields.status: Efforts underway to incorporate authorized data into Portal
fields.name: Turtles-Distribution and Nesting Areas (ESI)
fields.expected_date: As soon as vetted by Portal Data Review Team
fields.notes: ESI maps provide a concise summary of coastal resources that are at risk if an oil spill occurs nearby. Vector polygons in this data set represent turtle distribution.
fields.source: TNC NAM ERA compiled; source data from Environmental Sensitivity Index, NOAA
fields.description: Sea turtle areas displayed on the maps are limited to nesting beaches and several well-known in-water concentration areas. Sea turtle nesting beaches include sandy beach areas where sea turtles come ashore to nest.

fields.name: Port locations and attributes
fields.notes: Port locations are known, additional work is underway to work with port's stakeholders to develop relevant spatial data and information for each port.
fields.description: Locations of ports, how they relate to shipping traffic and their capacity for servicing offshore energy development

fields.name: Regional scale sea bird and sea duck predictive distribution model
fields.notes: BOEM-funded project underway to enable NCCOS to expand New York scale work to Mid-Atlantic region. Data expected in late 2012.
fields.description: A high resolution, predictive model for sea bird and sea duck habitat and distribution.

fields.name: Municipal and private discharge
fields.notes: In addition to point locations, effluent plume models would be useful for informing ocean planning efforts.
fields.description: Discharge of effluent from waste water treatment plants receiving waste water from households, commercial establishments and industries in the coastal drainage basin.

fields.status: Availability of suitable Mid-Atlantic specific models and model derived map layers is being evaluated.
fields.name: Ocean model results
fields.notes: FVCOM can be used for all of the NROC area and the northern part of MARCO area; additional modeling may be needed for MARCO.
fields.source: Potentially multiple sources including UMASS Dartmouth, Rutgers, Old Dominion University, MARACOOS and NERACOOS
fields.description: For example, Finite Volume Coastal Ocean Model (FVCOM) is a coastal ocean circulation model developed by UMASSD-WHOI that includes information on current, wave regime, temperature, salinity and density.

fields.name: State landings and fishing effort data
fields.expected_date: To be determined (beyond scope of current funding)
fields.notes: Most ocean fishery harvests are documented through federal reporting systems but there are gaps for some fisheries that do not require federal licenses.
fields.description: Information about commercial harvest activity collected by state agencies in the Mid-Atlantic.

fields.status: Efforts underway to incorporate authorized data into Portal
fields.name: Coldwater coral predictive distribution model
fields.notes: NCCOS and NEFSC working on a predictive model for the Mid-Atlantic.
fields.description: A high resolution, predictive model of coral habitat and distribution.

fields.name: Areas for non-fishing, non-boating recreational uses
fields.notes: Initial data is being collected via participatory GIS workshops with recreational stakeholders, summer 2012 and will continue through the fall and winter; these efforts will be supplemented by other surveys planned for 2013.
fields.source: Recreational users via MARCO stakeholder engagement efforts
fields.description: Areas where diving, surfing, swimming, nature viewing, etc. occur

fields.name: Sand, gravel, cobble mining locations; Identified resources
fields.source: Multiple agencies including ACOE, BOEM, States
fields.description: Resource areas where materials are actively mined from the sea floor and potential new mining areas.

fields.status: Efforts underway to incorporate authorized data into Portal
fields.name: Vessel Trip Report (VTR) data
fields.notes: VTR data are available upon request and can be posted on the portal at appropriate scale and with appropriate attribution. Data will need to be depicted in consideration of confidentiality requirements.
fields.description: Data on catch and value for many commercially important species aggregated to ten minute squares.

fields.status: Efforts underway to incorporate authorized data into Portal
fields.name: Marine Mammals-Sightings per Unit Effort (SPUE)
fields.expected_date: As soon as vetted by Portal Data Review Team
fields.notes: Need to add summary data layers with SPUE grids combined for multiple species and seasons (e.g. all toothed whales).  Assessed species include include fin whale, humpback whale, minke whale, northern Atlantic right whale, sperm whale, sei whale, Atlantic whitesided dolphin, bottlenose dolphin, harbor porpoise, and Atlantic striped dolphin.
fields.source: TNC NAM ERA compiled data;  source of data U.S. Navy Marine Resource Assessment (MRA) for the Northeast and Virginia Capes
fields.description: Important areas for marine mammals were determined from point sightings data. Data were assessed, combined and converted from seasonal species sightings into ten minute squares and effort-corrected. The resulting sightings per unit effort (SPUE) grids were used to identify important areas within the region for each species.

fields.name: Recreational fishing activity
fields.notes: Existing data on recreational fishing locations is of variable quality, resolution and geographic extent. Participatory GIS workshops with recreational fishery stakeholders began summer 2012 and will continue through the fall and winter; these efforts will be supplemented by other surveys planned for 2013.
fields.source: Recreational fishers via MARCO stakeholder engagement efforts
fields.description: Areas where non-commercial fishing (recreational/sport fishing) occurs.

fields.name: Energy facilities
fields.notes: In addition to point locations, plume models would be useful for informing ocean planning efforts.
fields.source: Multiple agencies including FERC, NREL, NRC, and the EPA
fields.description: Examples include nuclear power plant locations and their discharge pipe locations, potential/existing hydrokinetic sites, etc.
